American Truck Simulator has pros like realistic driving physics, detailed US landscapes, a relaxing atmosphere, and business management features. Cons include a less varied road network compared to its European counterpart, potential for repetitive gameplay, and a lack of extreme cargo options in the base game.

[h3][b]Pros[/b][/h3]
[list][*][b]Realistic and immersive:[/b] Features a 1:20 scale map of the United States, realistic physics, and detailed truck models. The AI is more alert and less prone to causing accidents, making for a smoother driving experience.
[*][b]Relaxing and atmospheric:[/b] Offers a chill, low-stress gameplay loop centered on driving. Players can enjoy the changing scenery and unique identity of different states, making it a great way to "soak in" the sights.
[*][b]Business management:[/b] Allows players to start their own trucking company, hire drivers, and manage a fleet of trucks and trailers.
[*][b]Deep customization:[/b] Offers extensive customization for trucks, with many options for paint jobs, accessories, and engine tuning.
[*][b]High replayability:[/b] With numerous DLC packs adding new states and jobs, the game has potential for long-term engagement, especially for those who enjoy simulation games. [/list]
[h3][b]Cons[/b][/h3]
[list][*][b]Less varied road network:[/b] The road network can be less dense and varied than in Euro Truck Simulator 2, with more large, flat stretches of highway.
[*][b]Repetitive gameplay:[/b] The core gameplay loop of picking up and delivering cargo can become repetitive, especially without mods or other DLC.
[*][b]Limited extreme loads:[/b] The base game does not include extreme cargo options like oversized or overweight trailers, which are available in other trucking simulations and may be added in future DLCs.
[*][b]No "quick travel" or "teleport":[/b] This is a pro for some, but for others it can be a con, as it removes the ability to skip driving parts of the map and requires players to drive the entire route, even for short trips. [/list]

Trucking sims were some of my first pc games from around 30 years back.  So, when ATS came out, it was an immediate buy, even though I didn't have a proper rig to immediately play it.  Fast forward to today and I pre-order every map pack upon learning about it.  I highly recommend a proper wheel kit (ex: HORI truck control system) and an eye tracker, but even without any of that, the experience is spot-on.  I've never personally driven a rig before, but I've ridden with a friend many times who did.  I've also watched numerous videos of former/current truckers also playing the game in their free time.  

I wish the world wasn't as scaled down (I believe I've read it's at 1:20 scale)...not to say I want anywhere remotely close to a 1:1 experience, but maybe 1:10 wouldn't be that bad?  I've been waiting till ATS gets to my home state of PA to see how the recreation goes, but recent bits I've been hearing does bring to light concerns about the eastern corridor and how close many cities along the East coast are, especially the northeast.  Philly, DC, Newark, and NYC are feared to be practically touching one another unless something else is figured out.  Maybe once the Mississippi is passed, the scale switches to 1:10 or 1:15?  

Scale aside, the only other thing that takes me out of the game is the lack of damage modeling, the ability for police to instantly fine you rather than you have to pull over first (spending time, etc), and likewise, how the towing system works.

I am the first to admit, driving a truck long distance... might be a little boring. It isn't a game for everyone. If you have ever played a "flow state" racing game. Making enough money to hire drivers to do more routes that drop money into your bank, steam rolling your cash flow. It has a odd feel, part management, part sim. All laden into a insanely massive recreation of the U.S. The DLC is on sale 4-5 times per year for dollars. When you start amassing states and they all become connected. It morphs into the largest map I have seen in gaming. To me, that was a huge pull to playing it and expanding my trucking company. And when you start driving, flowing, looking at the scenery. It is one of the best driving sim games ever created. Just remember, it isn't a racing game, but you can turn it into one.

American Truck Simulator's store page includes part of a review from Destructoid, in which the reviewer describes the experience of driving into Las Vegas at night while listening to Eric Clapton's "Wonderful Tonight". The reviewer also says that moment will probably stick with them forever. After reading that, I began to wonder if I would ever have a similar experience.

Then, one day...it happened.

I hadn't played in a couple of days, but I still had a delivery to finish. So I opened the game to do just that. One of my favorite things about ATS (and ETS2) is that it offers live radio. Listening to any of the variety of available stations is a really nice way to pass the time on long journeys. I tuned in to one called 80s Planet, and was treated to a number of great songs such as "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" by Tears for Fears, "Crazy Crazy Night" by KISS, and "The Way You Make Me Feel" by Michael Jackson, among others.

Then everything went quiet for a moment. I noticed the sun starting to rise. As it did, "True" by Spandau Ballet began playing. The stars must have aligned to make it happen right at that moment. Why that song? Because it's kind of a comfort song for me. It's special to me, just as "Wonderful Tonight" may be special to the Destructoid reviewer. To put it another way, listening to Spandau Ballet's "True" while driving a big rig at dawn through the New Mexico desert is something that will stick with me probably forever.

American Truck Simulator as a whole has become somewhat special to me partly because of little things like this. I can say the same for Euro Truck Simulator 2, although I haven't played that one as much as I've played ATS. If you're thinking of trying either one, I say go for it. Maybe you'll get to experience something just as pleasant as what I've described.

8.5/10

Firstly I want to say that this job is the reason I became a truck driver.  I fell in love with the idea of this career because of this game.  Anyone considering the career could start with this game before researching the industry further and deciding if its for them. 

That being said... This game is almost 10 years old and only 18 states are available.  As far as I can tell, all but three are still paid DLC.  That's fucking ridiculous.  My issue isn't that all 50, or even the contiguous 48 aren't available yet.  This team puts in a stupid amount of work and detail into these releases.  My problem is they still charge for DLC that came out in 2016.  SCS needs to start including older states in the base game as new states are released.

Would I recommend this game to other players? It really depends on what you're looking for and (!) how many money you want to spent. I love the game, but there are some reasons why I rather would say No than Go, and I chose to pull the "No" unfortunately despite being a great game.

I got used to ATS as a long time ETS2 player and ATS has some benefits in comparison to ETS2, but it also has some huge downsides.

Let's start with the advantages.

1.) Although the map scale is actually a tad smaller than ETS2 (ETS2: 1:19 - ATS: 1:20) if often feels bigger and more realistic than ETS2 because of the larger size of the countryside and increased distance between bigger cities in real life. That's a big pro for me.

2.) The game mechanics as a whole are equal to the ones in ETS2. Menus, Settings, 99% of the gameplay mechanics are identical. Yet, it is complete different experience to ETS2, because of the american topography, terrain, infrastructure, traffic rules, vehicles, etc. A big advantage of the american traffic system is that you can turn right on a red light. However, I feel that this is evened out by needing to wait for left turns longer at the intersections and their used system.

3.) Another advantage is that ATS offers (currently) a more immersive gameplay. You have the weigh stations, which you have to go to if your truck and trailer exceed a certain value, and the most times you do jobs you have to go to them. In ETS2, weigh and customs stations of that kind are optional if they offer any gameplay at all and are just a visual aspect.

4.) The trucks are so cool. A lot cooler than the ones in ETS2 with the big nose and the huge room in the back. But they also have disadvantages to the increased size up front and behind you. It's a lot more difficult to park and do driving manoveurs than in ETS2. With the big nose in front, you don't have as much space to park and vision to see on the roads. Also the big cabin sleep room (which is optional and not given for the Day Cab versions of the trucks, which by the way have window to the back which is very cool), can be a problem. And the trailers can be larger than the ones in europe as well. So parking and driving requires more effort and is more challenging than in ETS2.

Now let's come to the downsides in comparison to ETS2.

5.) The base map that comes free with the game just consists of California, Nevada and Arizona. For every other state of the US (doesn't matter how small), you need to pay full price for. While I personally think it's absolutely okay to charge for extra maps, I'm not so okay with the DLC policy of SCS Software for ATS like I do and highly appreciate for ETS2.

First of all, the base map is not as versatile as the one for ETS2. To 90% it covers desert zones only, which indeed displays a very important character of america but for anyone who wants to drive in more cooler climate zones, you have to pay for some extra map DLCs.  

Another aspect is that SCS Software decided to start in California (West) and then slowly progress to the east over the years. While 99% of ATS players are okay with that, I'm not. I think it's very bad that they decided to avoid the east coast of america in the past, present and the foreseeable future and rather focus on the midlands and now even British Colombia. New York, Florida and any other east coast states or areas (including canadian Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal and Quebec regions) will be still a long long long way to go to, which maybe (who knows what will be and happen in a few years) maybe never will come to fruition. This decision was and is wrong in my opinion. Many people come from these states and areas and also would like to have their areas represented in a game called "American Truck Simulator", not "West American Truck Simulator".

SCS did it very differently with ETS2, as they chose the free base map to consist of the map part of most popularity and importance for the main market to come first. And then build any additional areas from inside out. 

With these facts, I feel that ATS is unfortunately moreover in a category of being a cash grab, which other developers do and actually was the thing I liked so much on SCS Software in regard to ETS2. Every ETS2 DLC is reasonably and fair priced (even often undervalued for the maps offered if you ask me). I'm a bit disappointed by SCS Software, that they apparently did not chose the same way for ATS and push hands out for full price money even for the tiniest states. If you ask for full price on biggies like Texas and British Columbia with huge size and road network. No problem. I'm gladly willing to pay more for more effort. But not if you decide to charge for the smallest pieces of road networks in an equal way. SCS easily could have bundled 2 or 3 states together and then sell them in an equal way they did and do for SCS. But no they didn't.

My assumption is that due to mistakes in planning the location and amount of the free base map and the DLC strategy heading from the base map slowly to the north and east, it requires them to have and keep this business model because ATS has not nearly the same amount of players as ETS2 does. 

But it all depends on how the developers decide to build their game and continue to go forward with it.

I got used to ATS as a long time ETS2 player and ATS has some benefits in comparison to ETS2, but it also has some huge downsides.

Let's start with the advantages.

1.) Although the map scale is actually a tad smaller than ETS2 (ETS2: 1:19 - ATS: 1:20) if often feels bigger and more realistic than ETS2 because of the larger size of the countryside and increased distance between bigger cities in real life. That's a big pro for me.

2.) The game mechanics as a whole are equal to the ones in ETS2. Menus, Settings, 99% of the gameplay mechanics are identical. Yet, it is complete different experience to ETS2, because of the american topography, terrain, infrastructure, traffic rules, vehicles, etc. A big advantage of the american traffic system is that you can turn right on a red light. However, I feel that this is evened out by needing to wait for left turns longer at the intersections and their used system.

3.) Another advantage is that ATS offers (currently) a more immersive gameplay. You have the weigh stations, which you have to go to if your truck and trailer exceed a certain value, and the most times you do jobs you have to go to them. In ETS2, weigh and customs stations of that kind are optional if they offer any gameplay at all and are just a visual aspect.

4.) The trucks are so cool. A lot cooler than the ones in ETS2 with the big nose and the huge room in the back. But they also have disadvantages to the increased size up front and behind you. It's a lot more difficult to park and do driving manoveurs than in ETS2. With the big nose in front, you don't have as much space to park and vision to see on the roads. Also the big cabin sleep room (which is optional and not given for the Day Cab versions of the trucks, which by the way have window to the back which is very cool), can be a problem. And the trailers can be larger than the ones in europe as well. So parking and driving requires more effort and is more challenging than in ETS2.

Now let's come to the downsides in comparison to ETS2.

5.) The base map that comes free with the game just consists of California, Nevada and Arizona. For every other state of the US (doesn't matter how small), you need to pay full price for. While I personally think it's absolutely okay to charge for extra maps, I'm not so okay with the DLC policy of SCS Software for ATS like I do and highly appreciate for ETS2.

First of all, the base map is not as versatile as the one for ETS2. To 90% it covers desert zones only, which indeed displays a very important character of america but for anyone who wants to drive in more cooler climate zones, you have to pay for some extra map DLCs.  

Another aspect is that SCS Software decided to start in California (West) and then slowly progress to the east over the years. While 99% of ATS players are okay with that, I'm not. I think it's very bad that they decided to avoid the east coast of america in the past, present and the foreseeable future and rather focus on the midlands and now even British Colombia. New York, Florida and any other east coast states or areas (including canadian Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal and Quebec regions) will be still a long long long way to go to, which maybe (who knows what will be and happen in a few years) maybe never will come to fruition. This decision was and is wrong in my opinion. Many people come from these states and areas and also would like to have their areas represented in a game called "American Truck Simulator", not "West American Truck Simulator".

SCS did it very differently with ETS2, as they chose the free base map to consist of the map part of most popularity and importance for the main market to come first. And then build any additional areas from inside out. 

With these facts, I feel that ATS is unfortunately moreover in a category of being a cash grab, which other developers do and actually was the thing I liked so much on SCS Software in regard to ETS2. Every ETS2 DLC is reasonably and fair priced (even often undervalued for the maps offered if you ask me). I'm a bit disappointed by SCS Software, that they apparently did not chose the same way for ATS and push hands out for full price money even for the tiniest states. If you ask for full price on biggies like Texas and British Columbia with huge size and road network. No problem. I'm gladly willing to pay more for more effort. My assumption is that due to mistakes in planning the location and amount of the free base map and the DLC strategy heading from the base map slowly to the north and east, it requires them to have and keep this business model because ATS has not nearly the same amount of players as ETS2 does. 

But it all depends on how the developers decide to build their game and continue to go forward with it.
